description:
Chryseobacterium taichungense is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Taichung, Taiwan. It belongs to the genus Chryseobacterium, which is a group of Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacteria.

The cells of C. taichungense are rod-shaped, with a length of approximately 0.5-1.0 μm and a width of 0.3-0.5 μm. They are yellow-pigmented, due to the production of carotenoid compounds, and are motile with the help of gliding motility.

Phylogenetically, C. taichungense is closely related to other Chryseobacterium species, and its 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis has shown that it forms a distinct lineage within the genus. The optimum growth temperature for this bacterium is around 30°C, and it can grow in the presence of up to 2% (w/v) sodium chloride.

This species has been found to possess various hydrolytic enzymes, such as caseinase, amylase, and lipase, which may contribute to its environmental adaptability and potential applications in biotechnology or bioremediation processes.
